text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at South Korea
Daily Report -- Investigators publish new report on Engineering - Thermal
Engineering. According to news originating from Daejeon, South Korea, by
NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "A practical case of a single-phase
natural circulation (SPNC) loop having a considerable circulation length and
non-uniform structures is investigated via experimental and analytical
approaches. The target facility (Facility to Investigate Natural Circulation
in SMART, FINCLS) corresponds to the type of vertical heater and vertical
cooler (VHVC), and the maximum height and total circulation length are 12.2
and 34.5 m, respectively."

Financial support for this research came from National Research Foundation of
Korea (NRF) - Korea government (MSIT).

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Korea Atomic
Energy Research Institute, "A series of SPNC tests comprising 29 steady-state
conditions are performed under a wide range of working conditions: 0.5 MPa (60
degrees C) to 15.0 MPa (300 degrees C). Unexpected characteristics of the
natural circulation (NC) flow rate are observed for two test groups under
high-temperature conditions. An NC loop (NCL) model for a steady-state
solution that reflects both heat-loss and heat-sink effects is developed by
employing the lumped-component method and the moving-boundary algorithm."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The NC flow rates for
29 steady-state conditions predicted by the NCL model agree well with
measurements (within 5% error), and the unexpected characteristics of the NC
flow rate are clearly demonstrated via analysis of the NCL model."

For more information on this research see: Experimental Study On a Single-
phase Natural Circulation Loop and Its Steady-state Solution. _Applied Thermal
Engineering_ , 2020;173():. _Applied Thermal Engineering_ can be contacted at:
Pergamon-Elsevier Science Ltd, The Boulevard, Langford Lane, Kidlington,
Oxford OX5 1GB, England. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Applied Thermal Engineering -
<http://www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-thermal-engineering/>)

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained
from H.S. Park, Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, Innovat Syst Safety
Res Div, 989-111 Daedeokdaero, Yuseong 34057, Daejeon, South Korea. Additional
authors for this research include E. Yun and B.G. Jeon.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2020.115190>. This DOI is a link to
an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Studies from Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute Add New Findings in the Area of Thermal Engineering (Experimental Study On a Single-phase Natural Circulation Loop and Its Steady-state Solution): Engineering - Thermal Engineering
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at South Korea Daily Report -- Investigators publish new report on Engineering - Thermal Engineering. According to news originating from Daejeon, South Korea, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “A practical case of a single-phase natural circulation (SPNC) loop having a considerable circulation length and non-uniform structures is investigated via experimental and analytical approaches. The target facility (Facility to Investigate Natural Circulation in SMART, FINCLS) corresponds to the type of vertical heater and vertical cooler (VHVC), and the maximum height and total circulation length are 12.2 and 34.5 m, respectively.”

Financial support for this research came from National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) - Korea government (MSIT).

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, “A series of SPNC tests comprising 29 steady-state conditions are performed under a wide range of working conditions: 0.5 MPa (60 degrees C) to 15.0 MPa (300 degrees C). Unexpected characteristics of the natural circulation (NC) flow rate are observed for two test groups under high-temperature conditions. An NC loop (NCL) model for a steady-state solution that reflects both heat-loss and heat-sink effects is developed by employing the lumped-component method and the moving-boundary algorithm.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “The NC flow rates for 29 steady-state conditions predicted by the NCL model agree well with measurements (within 5% error), and the unexpected characteristics of the NC flow rate are clearly demonstrated via analysis of the NCL model.”

For more information on this research see: Experimental Study On a Single-phase Natural Circulation Loop and Its Steady-state Solution. Applied Thermal Engineering, 2020;173():. Applied Thermal Engineering can be contacted at: Pergamon-Elsevier Science Ltd, The Boulevard, Langford Lane, Kidlington, Oxford OX5 1GB, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Applied Thermal Engineering - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/applied-thermal-engineering/)

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from H.S. Park, Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, Innovat Syst Safety Res Div, 989-111 Daedeokdaero, Yuseong 34057, Daejeon, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include E. Yun and B.G. Jeon.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2020.115190. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
